content.description:
A delicate face climb on the wall between the two major crack climbs. Very popular.

Between the two major crack climbs (left = Recognition, right = Dreamberry Wine).
Bolts.

Start on the rail ledge and work your way up past a couple bolts following the path of least resistance, first right, then back left and finally right again for the finish. Bolts are set back about a meter past the top lip. Between Lycra and the Float Like a Butterfly sport route. 2 bolts and a light rack for a couple of placements.

Easy start into a 5.10 ish crimp section leading to the crux finish.

Dynamic or Static, choose your finish and commit!


Bolts

Awesome lay backing start into easy crack jamming fun.

Climbers right of the two major cracks.
Mostly BD #3 and 4...could take smaller up higher.

The big crack on the Left-hand side of Sorrows Other End Left. Climb up and out. This climb is located on Sorrows Other End Left wall.
This wall is the last one on the left hand side of Sorrows.
You can rap down from the anchors for Creme de la crimp or scramble down the right side of the wall. Trad anchor, two bolts then it's all you ...bring a #4,3,2 and a .75 that's it.

From the ledge you rapped to, traverse right to an off-width climb up the obvious crack.

Not accessible from the main cliff. Look for a two metre north-facing step on the top of the cliff. Rappel down the face from here to a ledge just above the water (Adventure Ledge).
Good gear. Taking your #4 is a good idea, Doubling on #3 isn't the worst idea if possible but not necessary.

Climb through thin but positive horizontal cracks to gain a ledge. The crux starts off the ledge and involves some balance, but is well protected.

Second sport route to the left of the blocky corner at the right side of the cliff.
4 bolts to rings

Climb up the face to a rest, and then climb the arete to the top!



Start to the right of transformer, and left of recognition.

Bolts with Bolted Anchor

This climb is similar to All The Rage directly to it's left. The start is hard, and climbs to a ledge. Off the ledge there is another crux before the climb slowly gets easier until you hit the top out. The anchor can be reached for top roping, but bring long slings as it is set way back from the edge.

Immediately left of the Dreamberry Wine Crack.
5 bolts, rap rings

climbs.name: Lycra, Spandex, and All Things Tight

content.description:
Despite the lycra reference, this is hardly a sport route (even for aging sport climbers who still wear lycra). Put on your Prana toque and crank up the delicate face past two bolts. Join the original finish to Double Rope Disaster.

2 bolts, & a piece or two of gear.

Climb the right hand crack from the "adventure ledge"and exit same as "excellent adventure" Save your number 3 for the end. From Sorrows other end right rap down from the anchors to the adventure ledge . SR ,#3 for end of climb.

Go up The Escapist then finish by climbing the right leaning crack to the top. This climb is on the Sorrows Other End Left wall. Two bolts down low,drop in a #4,3,2 and .75 where ever you want .
Use the anchors for Creme de la Crimp.

The obvious right-facing corner with wide crack. Great climbing on good pro.

G

Arguably the best trad line on the cliff, and one of the best in the province. The crux is encountered immediately after a flaring section of crack. Have fun, but don't get distracted by the rings under the roof to your left unless you plan to set a top rope. Instead top out by climbing out right from under the roof. You can use the anchor for transformer to get back down.

Scramble up onto the large detached block at the left side of the cliff and this climb is the first crack system you encounter.
Standard Rack to 3"

A tricky start leads to a high first bolt and a rest ledge. Off the ledge follow the bolts through two horizontals before making a short traverse to the right. Head up, following the bolts through the technical crux. Moving to the final horizontal at the top can be done statically or dynamically. It's big so choose your poison. An extended draw can be clipped before hitting the horizontal.

This is the steep slab/face climb immediately right of the Sea With Joy Crack system.
6 bolts and rap rings

Sorrow's End is a short cliff face in the Terrance bay area. It is the main cliff on the Halifax side of the harbor, and can see the odd busy day on weekends, but generally climbing here is much like anywhere else in NS - quiet. This cliff is well loved for both it's exposure to wind which helps with the bugs, and it's proximity to a lake. During the summer sun hit's the wall around noon and the best escape from the heat is to turn and walk 100 ft to the water! 
  
 The cliff was initially discovered by Nick Sagar. It has seen a lot of development over the years since. Most of the routes are recorded in the local guide book "Nova Scotia Rock", and it's 2010 digital update; however new routes are still being bolted.
